contentrichtext.text: '''Peter of Blois''' or '''Petrus Blesensis''' (c. 1135 – c. 1211) was a [[France|French]] poet and diplomat who wrote in [[Latin]]. Peter studied [[law]] in Bologna and [[theology]] in Paris. It was probably during his student years that he composed a number of Latin [[sequence (poetry)|sequence]]s after the manner of the [[Goliard]]s, some of which were preserved in the ''[[Carmina Burana]]'' collection. He also wrote ''Vacillantis trutine libramine''.<ref>William Doremus Paden - Medieval lyric: genres in historical context - Page 112 2000 - "Peter of Blois, "Vacillantis trutine," ed. Peter Dronke, The Medieval Poet and His World (Rome: Storia e Letteratura, 1984), 298-300. la Vacillantis trutine libramine mens suspensa fluctuat et estuat, in tumultus anxios dum se vertit et bipertit ..."</ref> Peter went with [[Stephen du Perche]] and [[Walter of the Mill]] to Sicily in 1166 and there became the tutor to King [[William II of Sicily]] in 1167. He was one of the few Frenchmen to survive the tumult of Stephen's years as chancellor of Sicily. Around 1173, he went to England, where he served [[Henry II of England|Henry II]] and successive [[archbishops of Canterbury]], [[Richard of Dover]], as a Latin secretary. He was appointed [[Dean (Christianity)|Dean]] of the [[St. Peter's Collegiate Church, Wolverhampton|College of Wolverhampton]], which he found corrupt. Resigning around 1202, he launched an ultimately unsuccessful bid to replace the institution with a [[Cistercian]] abbey.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=37876 Victoria County History: Staffordshire: Volume 3, n.44.]</ref> Around 1182 he was appointed [[Archdeacon of Bath]], a position he held for 26 years, followed by appointment as [[Archdeacon of London]] (1202â€“1212). He served as Latin secretary to [[Eleanor of Aquitaine]], Henry's widow. Many of his letters still survive. He is incorrectly associated with [[Pseudo-Ingulf]]'s ''[[Croyland Chronicle]]''. According to historian R.W. Southern, Peter's letters were widely read until the seventeenth century, "for pleasure and instruction by cultivated readers". They conveyed "moral, legal and theological instruction, and...satire on men and institutions".<ref>Southern,R.W. ''The Making of the Middle Ages'' (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1953) ISBN 0-300-00230-0 pp. 213-214</ref> His brother was [[William of Blois (poet)|William of Blois]], another poet, who is sometimes confused with [[William de Blois (bishop of Lincoln)|William de Blois]], the [[Bishop of Lincoln]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Sharpe, Richard |authorlink= Richard Sharpe (historian) |title=Handlist of the Latin Writers of Great Britain and Ireland Before 1540 |publisher=Brepols |location=Belgium |series=Publications of the Journal of Medieval Latin |volume=1 |edition=2001 revised |year=2001 |isbn=2-503-50575-9|page=754}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} * [[Joseph Armitage Robinson|Robinson, J.
